headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Nov. 5, 2011

headline: Welcome to the World, Please Take a Number
summary: This week sentiment tracker breaks down the online buzz about the United Nations estimate that the 7 billionth person was born this week.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: David Harsanyi on mobility and inequality in townhall.com, Nov. 2.

headline: Guys Enthralled by 'My Little Pony'
summary: A remake of "My Little Pony," an animated TV show originally conceived for little girls, has attracted a passionate fan base among grown men.

headline: General Removed for Karzai Remarks
summary: A senior U.S. military commander in Afghanistan was relieved of duty Friday night for making disparaging comments about the country's president and its top leadership, the U.S.-led coalition said.

headline: Colombia Officials: FARC Leader Killed
summary: Colombian soldiers killed Alfonso Cano, the top leader of Latin America's oldest and largest guerrilla insurgency in a bombing attack Friday, President Juan Manuel Santos said.

headline: Flood Leaves Bangkok Awash in Trash
summary: As floodwaters begin to surge into Thailand's capital after building for months further upstream, bundles of trash in the city's streets are becoming a headache for Bangkok's garbage collectors.

headline: Marathon Freeloaders Have Few Fans
summary: There's nothing illegal about jogging down city streets without a race bib, or even accepting refreshments. But in the running world,the offense is known as banditry.

headline: Virgin America Reservation Changeover Creates Bumpy Ride
summary: A week after Virgin America switched to a new reservations system, some customers say they still can't book, change or cancel flights online and that the airline's phones are jammed with callers.

headline: Jon Corzine Out at MF Global
summary: MF Global found out in recent days that about $659 million of its customer segregated accounts resided in an account at J.P. Morgan Chase. The announcement follows the resignation of Chief Executive Jon Corzine.

headline: Yangon's Many Faces of Change
summary: There is no more obvious sign that the door is cracking open in Myanmar than the sight of Aung San Suu Kyi's face everywhere.

headline: Popular Delusion of Bubble Spotting
summary: Spotting an investment bubble is never as easy as it looks after one bursts. Now, researchers are trying to build a better bubble detector. If history is any guide, you should be skeptical.

headline: Time Warner Bids for Endemol
summary: Time Warner is seeking to acquire Dutch TV production firm Endemol, which owns the rights to "Big Brother" and "Deal or No Deal."

headline: The Title-Molder
summary: In Hollywood he was revered for designing classic opening-title sequences for movies such as "Vertigo" and "The Man With the Golden Arm." But as shown by "Saul Bass: A Life in Film & Design," he also created much else, including corporate logos for Quaker Oats and United Airlines. Anthony Paletta reviews.

headline: Test Your Prediction Skills
summary: What's ahead for retail giant Macy's earnings?

headline: Bronxville's Name Goes Beyond Its Borders
summary: Bronxville is surrounded by Eastchester, Tuckahoe, Mount Vernon and Yonkers areas, each of which has a Bronxville postal address.

headline: Groupon IPO Cheers Valley
summary: Groupon closed at $26.11 a share in its first day of trading on Nasdaq, up 31% from its IPO price of $20.

headline: Marathon Sets Beat for Bands
summary: The 26.2-mile New York marathon course is a venue for more than 130 bands that will be giving a boost to the runners while entertaining spectators watching from the sidelines.

headline: On Photography: A Teacher, a Student and Three Books
summary: Current exhibitions of work by Lisette Model, Simon Norfolk and John Burke, and Lars Tunbjörk

headline: The Nuclear Option
summary: Aired only once, the "Daisy Girl" ad instantly ended Barry Goldwater's presidential campaign. Ken Kurson reviews "Daisy Petals and Mushroom Clouds."

headline: Playing the Big One: A Survival Guide
summary: It's a thrill to play a famous course like Pebble Beach, but it can also be overwhelming and joyless. Here are some tips.

headline: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Oct. 30
summary: With data from Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Living Fast and Dying Young
summary: The history of road-racing's golden era told through the story of Phil Hill, the first American-born driver to win the Grand Prix championship. Mark Yost reviews "The Limit."

headline: Washington Post Swings to Loss
summary: Washington Post Co. posted a quarterly loss on heavy charges, and education and publishing revenue remained weak.

headline: An Ordinary Man
summary: Reinhard Heydrich's engagement with Lina von Osten, his wife and a Nazi, led him toward a career in the SS and eventually made him one of the most dangerous men in Nazi Germany. Timothy Snyder reviews.

headline: Ushering the Old Masters Into the New World
summary: Samuel F.B. Morse's "Gallery of the Louvre" touted the virtues of the European grand tour, embracing genre, portraiture and interior scenery in a new type of history painting.

headline: Oppenheimers Farewell DeBeers
summary: Anglo American agreed to pay $5.1 billion in cash to buy the Oppenheimer family's shares in De Beers, raising Anglo American's stake in the world's biggest diamond company to about 85%.

headline: Harrisburg Could Have Done Worse
summary: Steven Malanga's "How Harrisburg Borrowed Itself Into Bankruptcy" (Cross Country, Oct. 29) gives the impression Harrisburg is the ne plus ultra of spendthrift recklessness.

headline: MF Global Crash Proves That Regulation Is Mistaken
summary: Regarding your editorial "Pulling a Corzine" (Nov. 1): Like all regulators, you have misdiagnosed the problem with our financial system. Having "very high capital standards" is not the solution. Capital standards are part of the problem.

headline: Giving Pedicabs a Shot
summary: Pedicabs are expensive and make you look like a tourist. But in a Midtown test against taxis, riding a rickshaw is sometimes the fastest way to go.

headline: The Green Man Whose Gardens Defy Gravity
summary: Since Biblical times, gardens have been horizontal, with flowers and plants sprouting out of the ground. Garden designer Patrick Blanc has turned that whole notion on its side, literally.

headline: Romney Offers Voucher Medicare Plan
summary: GOP presidential hopeful Mitt Romney waded into the sensitive issue of Medicare, proposing to offer future seniors a choice between the current fee-for-service federal health plan and a voucher to purchase health insurance from private carriers.

headline: How Many Artists Does It Take to Depict a Light Bulb?
summary: The Pace Gallery brings 37 artists' work together.

headline: Groupon Floats on Air
summary: Behind every bubble, there's a clever investment banker. This time around, it's Morgan Stanley's IPO deal for Groupon.

headline: Cuban Miami
summary: Three sunny days packed with the flavors and flair of the off-limits Caribbean island, with no travel embargo involved. Where to eat, sleep, shop, drive and meander.

headline: Europe Trembles, Cain Parries, MF Files
summary: The week in essential news, analysis, photos, graphics and stats.

headline: Agency Names Top Global Banks
summary: The enforcement agency for financial stability of the G-20 nations published the long-awaited list of those banks it will force to hold more capital because of their importance to the global financial system.

headline: Libyans Seek Secular Security Chief
summary: Many Libyan commanders are aligned behind a short list of candidates with no significant links to Islamist fighting groups to lead the army.

headline: Corzine Firm's Final Struggles
summary: While the MF Global's bankruptcy didn't cause a rerun of the panic unleashed by Lehman in 2008, the mess shows how quickly confidence can evaporate, especially in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: Shared Science Needs Peer Review
summary: I agree with Michael Nielsen that scientific information should be as open and accessible as possible ("The New Einsteins Will Be Scientists Who Share," Review, Oct. 29). However, I respectfully disagree with his disdain for publishing papers in scientific journals.

headline: Prime Signs of Pain Emerge
summary: Indexes that track the performance of mortgages taken out by credit-worthy borrowers have fallen an average of 5% in a little over a month.

headline: A Bills Game That Actually Matters
summary: The Jets go to Buffalo with both teams in the playoff hunt.

headline: Portrait of a General
summary: Otto Perez Molina stands to be the first Guatemalan president to come from the military since the civilian rule began. See some key dates in his military career.

headline: The Case for Emerging-Markets Bonds
summary: Investors used to look to emerging-market bonds to find higher yields. Now issuer nations are less indebted and have faster economic growth than U.S., Europe and Japan.

headline: Week in Words
summary: A field guide to unusual words in this week's Wall Street Journal.

headline: Art of the Drink
summary: With stylish illustrations evoking bartending manuals of a bygone era, "PDT" captures the current cocktail zeitgeist.

headline: Playing Politics With Your Investments
summary: Political risk poses a problem for investors that can't be addressed simply by diversifying assets. Here's what you need to know.

headline: Barnes: Government Unions Strike Back in Ohio
summary: They're spending $30 million to repeal the state's collective-bargaining reforms.

headline: Should You Pay for Disability Coverage?
summary: We explore five common myths about this oft-misunderstood employee benefit.

headline: The Beginning of the End
summary: The Battle of Midway changed the course of the Pacific war—and it wasn't just 'luck' that determined American victory. James D. Hornfischer reviews.

headline: A Coat for All Occasions
summary: Not too fancy nor too shabby, a navy jacket in a classic cut will take you everywhere you want to go.

headline: Wisecracks as Wisdom
summary: Author Steve Almond on the comic impulse.

headline: Dippin' Dots Tries to Avoid Meltdown
summary: Dippin' Dots, the self-described ice cream of the future, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, after fighting off foreclosure efforts by lender Regions Bank for more than a year.

headline: Playing U.S. Visa Lottery in Ethiopia
summary: For the past month, Ethiopia's post office has capitalized on lottery fever: That's the U.S. Diversity Visa Lottery, which allows millions of people from countries such as Bangladesh and Ukraine to apply for a drawing that could lead to a coveted U.S. green card.

headline: Job  Rise Shows Slow Recovery
summary: The U.S. job market strengthened in the past three months, signaling an economic recovery that is inching in the right direction but still vulnerable to global shocks.

headline: Greece to Form New Government
summary: Greece's Prime Minister George Papandreou narrowly survived a vote of confidence and vowed to start talks with all parties for the formation of a coalition government that will ratify a bailout package by Greece's creditors.

headline: Citi Shakes Up Executive Ranks
summary: The shake-up is the biggest since Chief Executive Vikram Pandit installed new leadership at the height of the financial crisis.

headline: What If Government Were More Like an iPod?
summary: Dilbert's Scott Adams on bringing democracy out of the age of wax candles and into the age of touch screens.

headline: Support For Rehab Centers
summary: Two separate shindigs benefiting celebrity-friendly rehabilitation centers were held in New York this week.

headline: FDA Approves Anticlotting Drug
summary: The FDA approved the latest in a class of new anticlotting drugs to prevent stroke—Xarelto from Johnson & Johnson and Bayer—but overruled its own staff's analysis in doing so.

headline: Tree Climbing's Natural High
summary: Tree climbing is no longer kids' stuff. With the right equipment and training, a killer view (and workout) can be yours.

headline: A Rock 'n' Roll Tour de Forest
summary: Rolling Stones pianist Chuck Leavell writes about a trip to Germany that helped green his world, and give him new purpose.

headline: Budget Fears Go Unspoken In Suffolk Bid
summary: Suffolk voters are set to decide between Democrat Steve Bellone Republican Angie Carpenter. The contenders have been unusually quiet on the biggest issue facing the county: a $135 million hole in the budget.

headline: Sale of N.J. Hospital Is Cleared
summary: The sale of New Jersey's oldest hospital to a for-profit medical group was finalized Friday, capping several years of turmoil since the city of Hoboken raised $52 million in bonds to rescue the ailing facility in 2007.

headline: Noonan: Happy Days Aren't Here Again
summary: Why the Democratic Party still lays claim to Americans' affection.

headline: Stricker: I'm Playing for Team USA in Australia
summary: Plus, the Big East Conference sues West Virginia as the Mountaineers look to flee to the Big 12.

headline: Senate Confirms Economic Adviser
summary: The Senate unanimously confirmed Alan Krueger as chairman of Obama's Council of Economic Advisors.

headline: BofA's Moynihan Flip-Flops Again
summary: Bank of America's plan to issue up to 400 million shares of new common stock is the latest in a string of flip-flops by CEO Brian Moynihan.

headline: Week in Ideas
summary: Picking baby's birthday, iPod togetherness and marriage moneyball.

headline: California Exports Much of Its Pollution
summary: The Irony in "California's New Green Tax" (Review & Outlook, Oct. 31) is that California imports much of its electricity, oil and gas from other states. If Californians truly believe in the environment, shouldn't they limit their consumption to energy produced in their state? Then they could enjoy the consequences of their actions.

headline: 'Mountains' Book, Paris Spa, Tie Case
summary: Climber Sandy Hill publishes a book of the world's best mountain photographs; Le Bristol in Paris overhauls its spa and Moore & Giles releases a great leather tie case.

headline: Medals of Honor
summary: A new book chronicles American military history through 150 pieces of regalia. Author Judith Price highlights a few glittering tales of war, peace and precious metal.

headline: Doctor Is Indicted in Medicare Case
summary: A New York-area family-practice doctor who was featured in a WSJ article about Medicare abuses last year was indicted by a federal grand jury this week for allegedly submitting more than $13 million of false claims to the program.

headline: Five Best: Max Hastings
summary: A selection of unforgettable eyewitness wartime accounts, including the collected letters of a 'ranker' in the Napoleonic Wars and the memoirs of a World War I pilot.

headline: Planting the Brightest Bulbs
summary: Three garden experts on their best (and worst) spring-bloomers.

headline: Tape Reveals Oligarchs' Dealings
summary: Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich was quizzed in court over a secret recording of a conversation he had in a Paris airport in 2000, which allegedly proves he shared ownership of the Russian oil company Sibneft with rival oligarch Boris Berezovsky.

headline: Fashion's New (Old) Thing
summary: How Martin Greenfield, the octogenarian tailor and maker of hand-sewn suits, became an edgy New York fashion brand.

headline: NYC's Finest: the Finishers
summary: The lifeblood of the New York City Marathon are the people who are just trying to survive it.

headline: Waking Up to Young Kids' Sleep Troubles
summary: OK, parents: With TV, the Web, homework and social events distracting children, it's time to set limits.

headline: Running for Fun and Fund Raising
summary: On Sunday, Drew Swiss will compete in the New York City Marathon, his 24th marathon. He has also raised $45,000 this year and $170,000 since 2007 for the New York Road Runners Team for Kids program.

headline: A Prize Born in Violence
summary: Hasselblad prize-winner Walid Raad is celebrated in a show.

headline: Gulf Oysters Suffer New Blow
summary: A prolonged swath of toxic algae in the Gulf of Mexico has delayed the start of the Texas oyster-harvesting season, in the latest blow to the Gulf oyster industry.

headline: Did 'Volatility Funds' Deliver?
summary: In choppy markets, some of these funds have lagged badly.

headline: Scones, Muffins and More
summary: In New York, there are many great places to have brunch. And then there are institutions. Sarabeth's Kitchen, which launched 30 years ago and has a new location in TriBeCa, falls squarely into the latter category.

headline: Conducting a New Language
summary: At first glance, composer Adam Rudolph's music looks like a Keno card. His conductor's score is even odder, resembling the notebook doodlings of a computer programmer. But to the 42 musicians who play in his Go: Organic Orchestra, the music makes perfect sense, thanks to intensive training from their leader.

headline: Photo-Op: Disc Man
summary: A look at the playfully satiric album covers of legendary illustrator Robert Crumb.

headline: Related Cos. Gets Subpoena in Fannie Probe
summary: The closely held New York developer was served with a subpoena as part of a federal inspector general's investigation of a business transaction with Fannie Mae, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Scotland Yard Arrests Sun Reporter in Probe
summary: British authorities arrested a 48-year-old reporter from News Corp.'s U.K. tabloid the Sun as part of a probe into police bribery, marking the first time a British scandal over tabloid reporting tactics has shifted the spotlight to the News of the World's weekday sister paper.

headline: More Horses, More Problems
summary: Vitaminwater co-founder Mike Repole has two chances to win the Breeders' Cup Classic: favorite Uncle Mo and Stay Thirsty.

headline: And Now for Some Real Opponents
summary: After a soft early-season schedule, the Giants face the Patriots in New England.

headline: The Best Thing Between Sliced Bread
summary: A look at sandwiches from around the world, from the new book "Scanwiches."

headline: Basic Human Nature: A User's Manual
summary: Matt Ridley on what's unchangeable—and changeable—about humanity.

headline: ETFs: Behind the Fee Cuts
summary: When an ETF switches indexes, investors should take notice—and not be taken in by temporary fee cuts.

headline: Art in the Ozarks
summary: Why should museums be stuck in cities? Holly Finn on the new Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Ailing Italy Accepts IMF Monitoring
summary: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi rejected an offer of financial aid from the IMF, but accepted monitoring of his policies in a bid to restore investor confidence in the country.

headline: From Vintage to Modern
summary: A line of restored vintage clothing makes its debut.

headline: Medals of Honor
summary: A new book chronicles American military history through 150 pieces of regalia. Author Judith Price highlights a few glittering tales of war, peace and precious metal.

headline: Paneed Rabbit With Citrus, Sage and Caper-Butter Sauce
summary: The last of four easy-enough recipes by chef Stephen Stryjewski of Cochon in New Orleans.

headline: Ideas Calendar: Nov. 5-11
summary: The Society for Judgment and Decision Making meets in Seattle; the World Puzzle and Sudoku Championships come to Hungary; Umberto Eco speaks in Philadelphia; the New York Public Library hosts Rolex Arts Weekend.

headline: Star Runners Go the Distance for Youth
summary: The New York Road Runners hosted its third annual fund-raiser for its youth running programs.

headline: MF Global Probe Expands
summary: Federal prosecutors have joined the government's fast-expanding investigation into the collapse of securities firm MF Global Holdings Ltd. and its former head, Jon Corzine, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: At Yahoo, Yang's Dual Roles Are Under Fire
summary: Jerry Yang's multiple hats at Yahoo have raised questions about whether the  co-founder and director can act in the best interest of shareholders. On Friday, hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb demanded Yang resign from the board.

headline: New Limit Is Too Low  For New York City
summary: I almost never disagree with a Journal editorial, but I can't believe how out of touch you are about housing prices in New York City ("Senators for McMansion Subsidies," Oct. 22).

headline: Obama Leaves G-20 Empty-Handed
summary: President Barack Obama traveled overseas this week to try to cajole European leaders to resolve a debt crisis that could weaken the U.S. economy. He left largely empty-handed.

headline: St. Vincent's Site Is Rising
summary: In a building that was once part of the St. Vincent's Hospital campus, doctors' offices have been replaced with light-filled kitchens as the first signs of a rebirth emerge at the bitterly fought-over site.

headline: In the Mood for Crackle and Pop
summary: Living Well columnist Rita Konig's favorite sources for log baskets, candlesticks and snuggly rugs.

headline: Taking the Earth's Temperature
summary: Recent disputes demonstrate the surprisingly statistical and uncertain nature of tracking global temperature.

headline: Finding the Origin of the Vile
summary: In "The Prague Cemetery," novelist Umberto Eco imagines an evil mastermind who foments anti-Semitism in 19th-century Europe. Peter Orner's "Love and Shame and Love" follows three generations of a Jewish family in Chicago, but the focus is on the grandson, a neurotic narrator who seems to have inherited an aptitude for failed relationships.

headline: Syria Asks Civilians to Disarm
summary: Syria's government called on citizens carrying arms to turn in themselves and their arms within a week, dealing a new setback to a plan brokered by Arab leaders this week to end Syria's deadly crisis.

headline: Death-Defying Values of Savigny-lès-Beaune
summary: Savigny-lès-Beaune is one of the less-celebrated appellations of Burgundy, but Jay McInerney finds that its obscurity makes for some great values, especially in the context of the great 2009 vintage.

headline: Berkshire Net Falls 24%
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway said its third-quarter profit fell 24% on steep derivative losses, though operating earnings were stronger than expected.

headline: Design Flair for the Least-Stylish Devices
summary: Medical supply companies are retooling products to hide any hint of medical components. They are fashioning sleeker packaging to stand out on shelves and in hopes that big-box and drug stores will carry more of their products.

headline: Obama Has Learned From FDR, but This Isn't 1936
summary: Regarding Paul Moreno's "Obama's Re-Election Model Is FDR" (op-ed, Oct. 24) excoriating Franklin Roosevelt's re-election strategy in 1936: The strategy worked.

headline: Aging Population Eases Jobless Rate
summary: The nation's unemployment rate may fall faster in the future than many economists assume for one simple reason: The rapid aging of the American work force is helping reduce the share of the population hunting for jobs.

headline: Alexander McQueen Shoes
summary: $1,645 buys you crystal embellished evening peep-toes with an S-curve heel, or a fashion fanatic's wardrobe.

headline: A Buffett Devotee Riles His Targets
summary: Sardar Biglari, a Texas investor who has styled himself as a smaller version of Warren Buffett, isn't content to run the Steak 'n Shake restaurant chain. He has now set his sights on Cracker Barrel.

headline: Guatemala Opens Inquiry Into Disappearance
summary: Nearly two decades after rebel fighter Efrain Bámaca went missing, the Guatemalan attorney general's office has opened an investigation into Mr. Bámaca's death and the role of Otto Pérez Molina.

headline: Drug War Boosts Ex-General
summary: On Sunday, Guatemala holds elections expected to make Otto Pérez Molina the next president. He would be the first former military officer to take power since a 1996 agreement ended a conflict that killed an estimated 200,000 people.

headline: The Young and the Riskless
summary: Twentysomethings are seeking safety from market volatility at precisely the wrong moment in their investing lives. Here's how to get back on track.

headline: Neal Freeman: Buckley, If Not God, Returns to Yale
summary: What the late, great controversialist would have said to Mitt Romney, Rick Perry and today's conservative talking heads.

headline: Salads Dressed for Fall
summary: Roasted, toasted, poached and flash-fried toppings turn greens into cozy meals.
